Posts.Content: You should make an appointment with a gynocoligist to check out your discharge. 4 months is long enough, do not wait anymore. Better safe than sorry.
Posts.Title: im 17 and with nipple discharge? im so scared! someone please help me out

Posts.Content: I am sorry to hear about your mom. After reading her last two messages, I actually began to have hope with this particular type of cancer. I have been reading messages on this website since my very dear friend was diagnosed in February 07.  She was diagnosed with breast cancer in June 06, was treated, and seemed to be "cancer free" that November. However, she was one of the 5 out of 100 that get CM as a result of breast cancer. She had a port put into her head and began treatments. Everything seemed to be progressing until this past summer we noticed changes in her. She began to forget things, she said off the wall comments, seemed to hallucinate occasionally, became very paranoid, and just wasn't herself.  After telling the doctors about these symptoms, it turned out the lining of her brain became inflamed as a result of the injections to her port. With this being said, she slowly regressed as the weeks went on. The month of November was awful. She could not move her legs, became paralyzed on the left side of her body, was unable to get out of bed, her pain grew worse, she was not able to eat, only drink out of a straw, her speech was slurred, and all we could do was sit at her bedside and watch our friend suffer. As I sat there, I thought of the way she used to be, fun loving, high spirited 35 year old woman who was withering away right before my eyes. She went on like this for 5 weeks until she passed away last week. I don't know what was worse, watching her suffer and fade away, or knowing she is now at peace and will never suffer or feel pain again. It is very tragic and unfair and I will miss her so much.
Posts.Title: Treatment for: carcinomatous meningitis

Posts.Content: On 6/3/2008 curenow wrote: Hi - My sister was diagnosed with CM in early April 08 and was diagnosed a year ago with Breast Cancer and received a double masectomy followed by chemo and radiation.  Since her CM diagnosis, she has had an omaya res and then a shunt placed in her head to keep her swelling to a minimum and she has tried thiotepa 1X and then metetrexate 2X.  We believe that the methotrexate is not working because after her last treatment, she had two seisures and her condition and side effects have worsened.  Can anyone share what other treatments they are receiving and how they are doing?  Thank you.   How is your sister doing?
Posts.Title: Treatment for: carcinomatous meningitis

Posts.Content: On 8/20/2008 Leslie78 wrote:   On 8/20/2008 principal wrote:   On 6/3/2008 curenow wrote: Hi - My sister was diagnosed with CM in early April 08 and was diagnosed a year ago with Breast Cancer and received a double masectomy followed by chemo and radiation.  Since her CM diagnosis, she has had an omaya res and then a shunt placed in her head to keep her swelling to a minimum and she has tried thiotepa 1X and then metetrexate 2X.  We believe that the methotrexate is not working because after her last treatment, she had two seisures and her condition and side effects have worsened.  Can anyone share what other treatments they are receiving and how they are doing?  Thank you.   How is your sister doing?She is not doing so well. She lost most of her vision and has had a few vp shunt revisions due to infections or her filter clogging with cancer cells.  The most recent shunt surgery was two days ago where she had to have the shunt removed because it was infected.  She has not gotten any chemo in over a month because she was in the middle of being reevaluated (via PET, CT, etc.) to see if the methotrexate was working.  Her cell count was up. She currently has other complications as well. There is a lot of fluid in her lungs and her left side (neck and arm).  At this point, we are trying to make her comfortable by allevating the pain she is experiencing as the cancer has made it to the bone level.   I'm so sorry to hear that. I was hoping for better news. How old is she?
Posts.Title: Treatment for: carcinomatous meningitis

Posts.Content: On 7/4/2008 LoveandLight wrote: I just wanted to tell everyone that my mother, "Lodoma" died peacefully on June 24th,2008. She was cognitive up until the end and pain free thanks to the wonderful people at hospice in Vermont. She tracked this message board until her vision declined in May and felt tremendous gratitude for all the messages and support. She is now dancing in the light. Much love and light to all who are struggling with this disease and have love ones struggling with this disease. What I learned holding my mother when she passed is that this life is only a small fragment in our soul's journey.  Love and light. I am so sorry your mom died. I was following her progress on this website through your updates. My friend passed away last December from CM. Prior to that, I had hope from reading about your moms progress and now it has come to an end. I am sad for you. I had hoped your mom would be one of the first to overcome this horrible disease. I am truly sorry for your loss.
Posts.Title: Treatment for: carcinomatous meningitis

Posts.Content: On 10/10/2008 Mad Scientist wrote: I'm not sure how active this board might be anymore, but in my search for some answers and/or understanding, I came across your stories and struggles and draw courage from you all.  You have already helped me, but if anyone has information to any of my questions, I'd be very grateful.    About 6 years ago my mom (62 years old now) was diagnosed with breast cancer.  Mastectomy, chemotherapy...  remission for 5 years.  About a year ago she was experiencing some cognitive difficulties, mixing up words, forgetting things, etc.  Metastatic brain tumor...  brain surgery...  it grows back in the void left from the surgery and it's in the in brain fluid...  full brain radiation hasn't shrunk it and now the diagnosis is probably CM, pending spinal taps...  My question(s)...  does anyone know if the prognosis is affected by how quickly the CM is found and treatment begun?  Common sense would obviously say that it would help, but with what I've been reading on the board I'm wondering if it is an unwinnable fight, regardless...  My mom's not experienced any of the muscle weakness, leg failure, blurred vision, or any of the symptoms that seem to be associated with later stages...  does this give her a better chance to beat this cancer?  Can she beat this cancer?  Everything I read looks so bleak...  is there hope?   Have people overcome CM?   Hi, I am so sorry about your mom. Since you have read all of the messages, I'm sure you read the one about the woman who lived over 4 years with CM. So I do believe anything is possible. I do not know if there is a cure, however I did read a lot of new information that in Europe they are trying experimental chemo/radiation to the brain and spine at the same time and they are seeing results. I don't know if that information can help you in anyway. I hope you receive some positive news from the spinal tap results. What state does your mom live in?
